abstract.p: Changing aircraft operational procedures is one way of mitigating the environmental impacts of aviation in relatively short timeframes with existing aircraft types. However, to date these mitigations have not been evaluated or compared in a systematic manner that considers both their environmental impact reduction potential and their ability to be successfully implemented. This article presents a comprehensive identification and systematic evaluation of potential near-term operational changes to determine their relative environmental mitigation benefits. The research also evaluated the potential for successful implementation by identifying possible barriers to implementation for each mitigation. The analysis identifies the most promising mitigations offering a combination of environmental impact reduction and ease of implementation.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: There is increasing pressure on the aviation community to mitigate the environmental impacts of aviation.1,2 Various mitigation strategies are being pursued, including developing advanced aircraft technologies and sustainable alternative jet fuels, creating new policies and standards, and modifying operational procedures. New technologies can reduce environmental impacts significantly but require long timeframes due to the slow turnover of aircraft fleets. Sustainable jet fuels can also reduce environmental impacts significantly but drop-in fuels will not be commercially available in large quantities in the near-term, and other potential fuels will require aircraft adaptations. In contrast, while operational changes have smaller overall mitigation potential, they can be implemented in much shorter timeframes with existing aircraft types. Such changes offer an important near-term complement to the longer term approaches. For the purposes of this study, near-term is defined as having potential to be implemented within the next 5–10 years.

Operational mitigations specific to given flight phases have been suggested and investigated at various depths. For example, continuous descent approaches (CDA, now evolving into optimized profile descents (OPD)) have been investigated extensively through field trials and are now fully operational at some airports, showing notable environmental impact reduction.3,4 Work on advanced surface congestion management is in the research and field prototype stage5 and more widespread application is expected soon, while other possible changes have yet to be fully defined, let alone studied in any significant depth. There is also growing interest from the air navigation service providers to understand the role that operational strategies available in each flight phase have on total mission fuel burn (and hence emissions), as illustrated by the Atlantic Interoperability Initiative to Reduce Emissions (AIRE) and Asia and South Pacific Initiative to Reduce Emissions (ASPIRE) programs.6,7 The Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) Next Generation Air Transportation System (NextGen) and EUROCONTROL Single European Sky ATM Research (SESAR) have also identified some near-term operational strategies that will be needed to achieve the desired system evolution, such as the NextGen Operational Improvements (OIs).8

The study presented here complements these activities by identifying and systematically evaluating a comprehensive set of potential near-term operational mitigations across all flight phases against a common set of environmental impact and feasibility criteria to help identify promising areas for further work. This article is an extension of the work described in Reynolds et al.9

The remainder of this article is organized as follows. Section ‘Operational mitigations identification’ discusses the identification of mitigations. Section ‘Operational mitigations assessment’ presents the analysis approach and the ‘Results’ section presents the results. The section following these discusses the topics selected for further study. The final section gives conclusions and next steps from this study.

sec.title: Operational mitigations identification
sec.p: The first objective of this research was to identify a comprehensive list of near-term operational mitigations to include in the study. While many mitigations have been proposed and several are in use, relatively few are formally documented, and knowledge of them is fragmented and distributed across a wide range of stakeholders in industry, academia, and the government. A combination of literature review, domain expertise and extensive stakeholder interviews was used to identify appropriate operational mitigations for this study.

To ensure a diversity of viewpoints, 23 interview subjects from 11 stakeholder groups across the civil aviation industry were targeted, including the regulators and policymakers, Air Traffic Control (ATC), airlines, airports and research organizations, as shown in Table 1. On completion of the interviews and literature review, the team distilled a comprehensive list of over 75 possible near-term mitigation options, barriers and other key comments. While the full set of mitigations was primarily operational in nature, it also included factors raised by the stakeholders such as airline strategy (e.g. non-revenue flying, load factors) and non-operational policy (e.g. land use planning). This article focuses on the set of 61 purely operational mitigations identified from the process described above.

sec.title: Operational mitigations assessment
sec.p:
The team developed a rating system to perform an iterative evaluation of the mitigation options. First, the mitigations were classified according to the phase of flight to which they applied.
Surface, covering all gate and taxiing operations.
Departure, covering all take-off and climb operations.
Cruise, covering operations from top of climb to top of descent.
Approach, covering top of descent to landing.
Miscellaneous, for elements impacting multiple flight phases.

Figure 1 shows the distribution of these mitigations amongst the flight phases. Figure 1.
Operational mitigations by flight phase.

The extent of the mitigation’s impact was evaluated in each of four environmental impact categories (Fuel burn reduction, Climate impact reduction, Air quality impact reduction, and Noise reduction) as follows.
Primary (P): Primary goal is to reduce environmental impact in that category. For example, noise-minimizing trajectories have a primary goal of reducing noise.
Secondary (S): Primary goal/impact is reduction in another category, but the mitigation also yields benefits in that category. For example, surface taxi route optimization is focused on reducing fuel burn, but also yields reduced emissions, benefiting climate and air quality.
Neutral (0): No impact in that category. For example, changing cruise operations has no impact on noise around airports.
Adverse (A): Increases the adverse environmental impact in that category. For example, noise-minimizing trajectories which require longer flight paths may increase fuel use and emissions, adversely impacting fuel, climate, and air quality.

In addition, the ease of implementation of each mitigation was rated as follows.
Easy: Mitigations such as ground power and air conditioning that have already been successfully implemented, or mitigations such as reduced-engine taxiing that do not require significant stakeholder change or technical development.
Medium: Mitigations requiring relatively limited infrastructure additions such as end-around taxi ways or increased use of existing technology, such as area navigation/required navigation performance (RNAV/RNP) precision procedures.
Hard: Mitigations such as automation development facing significant new technical development, stakeholder opposition and/or lengthy procedural review (such as major airspace changes).

Finally, the potential system-wide impact of each mitigation was rated as Strong, Moderate, or Weak depending on their estimated relative impacts at a system-wide level. So, for example, a mitigation that had potential to significantly reduce fuel burn in a given flight phase, but that phase is a small proportion of overall fuel burn would have a ‘moderate’ or ‘weak’ system-wide impact categorization depending on expected magnitudes. By contrast, a mitigation that has a bigger impact on total system fuel burn would be ranked as ‘strong.’

This process allowed us to systematically evaluate and compare the mitigations. Classification according to the assessment criteria was subjective, but the process was refined and consensus built through several iterations within the research team, with the FAA and through further interaction with key stakeholders from the interview process. As exploration of specific mitigations continues, these estimates are likely to evolve.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: The results of the operational mitigations assessment are shown in the following tables. For each, the qualitative assessment ranking consistent with the criteria discussed in the previous section is provided, along with a brief description of the characteristics of the mitigation and the rationale for the rankings shown.

From this process it is possible to compare mitigations and identify those most promising for further study and possible implementation. These generally have high system-wide impact potential coupled with relatively easy implementation in near-term timeframes.

sec.title: Surface (S)
sec.p:
Nominal surface operations account for a relatively small proportion of total system fuel burn, but a significant proportion of delay is incurred in this phase and hence there are opportunities for meaningful environmental impact reductions. Table 2 shows the results of the surface mitigations evaluation. Table 2.

S-1: Surface congestion management systems
S-1.1: Simple systems (procedure-based) Simple surface congestion management strategies that modify the way existing surface operations are managed through basic procedural changes have potential for mitigating surface emissions. For example, keeping aircraft on the gate for longer during periods of congestion can limit the buildup of queues on the airport surface and hence decrease taxi times, fuel burn and emissions. S-2: Taxi fuel minimization
S-2.1: Surface taxi route optimization Assigning the shortest taxi path to departing or arriving aircraft to minimize taxi fuel burn. S-2.2: Reduced-engine taxi This approach involves using less than the full complement of engines for taxiing. For twin-engine aircraft, this implies taxiing with a single engine operational. Using fewer engines for taxi results in a decrease in the total fuel burn. Primary Fuel: Use of fewer engines to taxi is motivated by fuel saving; Secondary Climate, Air Quality: Reduced taxi fuel burn leads to secondary climate and air quality benefits; Neutral Noise: Uses fewer engines but at higher thrust on those operating, increasing noise per engine; Easy: Does not require any major policy or stakeholder changes and it has already been successfully implemented in the past (although there can be pilot reluctance due to operational issues such as those arising from engine start problems); Moderate: these strategies can be implemented at a wide range of airports and offer moderate fuel savings at each as long as they are implemented by a large number of flights (extent of current usage is unclear).
P S S 0 Easy Mod
S-2.3: Operational tow-outs Saves departure taxi fuel by towing aircraft out to departure runway using a tug. During departure tow-outs, the engines are not turned on until five minutes before takeoff (for warm-up). Aircraft emissions decrease, but tug emissions are introduced. This procedure is also known as dispatch towing. Primary Fuel: Use of tugs is motivated by fuel saving; Secondary Climate, Air Quality, Noise: Reduced engine use for taxi leads to secondary climate, air quality and noise benefits; Medium: Does not require any major policy or stakeholder changes and has already been successfully implemented in the past, but airports likely to need to acquire additions clean tug capacity and an efficient way to return tugs to ramps; Moderate: these strategies can be implemented at a wide range of airports and offer moderate fuel savings at each as long as they are implemented by a large number of flights.

S-2.4: Harvesting ASDE-X data Airport Surface Detection Equipment-X (ASDE-X) is an airport surface surveillance system that provides aircraft and ground vehicle identification to ATC. It enables better surface congestion management (e.g., S-1) and improved surface situation awareness which may increase controller efficiency in managing taxiways and runways. Secondary Fuel, Climate, Air Quality, Noise: Primarily developed for improving surface situational awareness for ATC. Benefits of reduced taxi time lead to secondary fuel, climate, air quality and noise benefits; Easy: For airports already equipped with ASDE-X systems, analyzing it does not require any major policy or stakeholder changes, has already been successfully performed for some airports; Moderate: Potential savings may be small at any given airport, but they can be implemented widely.
S S S S Easy Mod
S-2.5: APU management The Auxiliary Power Unit (APU) generates power and conditioned air for aircraft on the surface when their engines are off. By better managing when and how the APU is used (e.g. by using ground power (see S-6) and air when available at a gate), fuel savings can be achieved. Primary Fuel: Mitigation motivated by fuel saving; Secondary Climate, Air Quality: Reduced APU fuel burn leads to secondary climate and air quality benefits; Neutral Noise: APU not a major source of noise impacts; Easy: Has already been implemented; Weak: Can be implemented widely but offers only minimal fuel savings.

S-3.1: Assign departure runway to minimize taxi or airborne distance Assigning aircraft to departure runways that gives the shortest ground taxi distance or time given the gate the aircraft is coming from, or assigning for minimum air distance given departure fix. Minimum taxi time may be different than minimum taxi distance when there is surface congestion. S-3.2: Assigning arrival runway closest to gate or w/minimal air time Assigning aircraft to arrival runways that gives the shortest air distance given arrival fix or ground taxi distance or time given the gate the aircraft is going to. Minimum taxi time may be different than minimum taxi distance when there is surface congestion. Secondary Fuel, Climate, Air Quality: Developed primarily for surface or TRACON efficiency which minimizes taxi or TRACON distance and hence has secondary environmental benefits; Neutral Noise: Taxiing aircraft have minimal noise impact, airborne impact depends on population distribution relative to airborne path; Easy/Medium: Easy procedure-based if simply shortest distance, medium if automation needed to allocate for minimum time accounting for congestion; Weak: Can be implemented at a wide range of airports, but potential environmental benefit is small at each.
S S S 0 Easy/Med Weak
S-3.3: Preference to best runway for largest aircraft Generally, larger aircraft have higher fuel burn and emissions rates than smaller aircraft. Therefore, when the largest aircraft is given priority to the best runways, fuel burn and emissions benefits should be seen. Primary Fuel: Motivation for this mitigation is net fuel reduction; Secondary Climate, Air Quality: Reduced fuel use from big aircraft have secondary climate and air quality benefits; Neutral Noise: no clear impact on noise impacts; Easy: Simple procedure-based implementation; Weak: Can be implemented at a wide range of airports, but potential environmental benefit is small.
P S S 0 Easy Weak
S-4: Improved airport taxiway configurations
S-4.1: End-around taxiways to minimize crossing queues Perimeter taxiways or end-around taxiways minimize active runway crossings during peak periods. Can enhance capacity/reduce delay by permitting uninterrupted take-offs and landings on the runways. Secondary Fuel, Climate, Air Quality: Primary motivation is increased throughput/reduced delay, but this leads to secondary savings in fuel, climate and air quality impacts; Neutral Noise: Some reduced noise from aircraft delay reduction, but this is minimal and may be offset by more noise from taxiing aircraft using the end-around taxiway if this sends aircraft closer to the airport perimeter; Medium: Relies on some infrastructure addition; Weak/Moderate: Can be implemented at a wide range of airports, but potential environmental benefit depends on effectiveness in reducing delay at any given airport.
S S S 0 Med Weak/Mod
S-4.2: Improved locations of high-speed turn-offs to minimize taxi If a runway exit is too close to the landing point, the speed of most aircraft will be too high to make the exit. In contrast, if the exit is too far down the runway, aircraft will have to extend their landing roll (increasing taxi time, runway occupancy time and possibly decreasing capacity) and may end up further away from the terminal area than necessary. Improved locations of high-speed turnoffs can reduce these effects, saving the airlines fuel and providing a potential air quality benefit. Moreover, because landing aircraft would be able to exit the runway sooner, aircraft queued for departure can depart sooner. Secondary Fuel, Climate, Air Quality: Primary motivation is increased throughput/reduced delay, but this leads to secondary savings in fuel, climate and air quality impacts; Neutral Noise: No obvious effect on noise; Medium: Relies on some infrastructure addition; Weak/Moderate: Can be implemented at a wide range of airports, but potential environmental benefit depends on effectiveness in reducing delay at any given airport.
S S S 0 Med Weak/Mod
S-4.3: Holding or passing areas near runway ends Hold or passing areas near runway ends allow re-sequencing of aircraft. This can maximize throughput of a runway by allowing optimized sequencing of flights as well as preventing an aircraft blocking a departure queue when it is unable to depart due to ATC constraints, equipment issues, performance number delays, or other constraints. Secondary Fuel, Climate, Air Quality: Primary motivation is increased throughput/reduced delay, but this leads to secondary savings in fuel, climate and air quality impacts; Neutral Noise: No obvious effect on noise; Medium: Relies on infrastructure addition; Moderate: If it could be implemented at a wide range of airports, throughput increases could lead to moderate benefit level.
S S S 0 Med Mod
S-5: Improved coordination tools
S-5.1: Improved info sharing & operator situational awareness tools Improving communication of unexpected congestion, downstream constraints and flight-specific data such expected departure clearance times (EDCTs) would allow more efficient handling of these events, increasing throughput and reducing delay. Secondary Fuel, Climate, Air Quality: Primary motivation is increased throughput/reduced delay, but this leads to secondary savings in fuel, climate and air quality impacts; Neutral Noise: No obvious effect on noise; Medium: Requires new tools and procedures; Strong: Could impact operator decisions across entire network.
S S S 0 Med Strong
S-5.2: Flight plan change delivery over datalink During weather events, flight plan re-routes may not be finalized until the aircraft are near the front of the departure queue. Currently re-routes are done by voice which are slow and can create blocking in queues, leading to excess time and fuel burn for those aircraft behind. Datalink delivery could reduce some of these issues. Secondary Fuel, Climate, Air Quality: Primary motivation is increased throughput/reduced delay, but this leads to secondary savings in fuel, climate and air quality impacts; Neutral Noise: No obvious effect on noise; Medium: Requires new tools and procedures; Weak: More relevant at some airports than others. Relatively small number of times this mitigation would provide benefits system-wide.
S S S 0 Med Weak
S-6: Ground power for aircraft around airport When aircraft have access to ground power, the pilot need not turn on the APU and hence could save fuel on the surface. If ground power was available at other locations (e.g. Hard Stands), APU use would be lower still. (Complementary to S-2.5). Primary Fuel: Motivated by APU fuel saving; Secondary Climate, Air Quality: Reduced fuel use has secondary climate and air quality benefits; Neutral Noise: APU is not a major source of noise; Easy/Medium: Making greater use of available ground power at gate, or installing additional units; Weak: Can be implemented at a wide range of airports, but potential environmental benefit is relatively small at each because fuel burn from the APU at the gate is small.

D-1: Departure procedures
D-1.1: Intersection departures Depart further down the runway than standard. Used to expedite traffic by saving time in taxi and departure queues. More engine power might have to be used compared to if the entire runway length was used in the take-off. Neutral Fuel, Climate, Air Quality, Noise: Offers limited fuel, emissions and noise savings because any benefits associated with increases in throughput are likely to be offset by higher thrust which might be required for a shorter runway takeoff, so net effect is close to zero; Easy: Does not require any extra equipment, technical development or stakeholder changes; Weak: Can be implemented at a wide range of airports, but potential benefits are small.
0 0 0 0 Easy Weak
D-1.2: Noise abatement departure procedures Noise abatement departure procedures are typically designed to get aircraft high quickly while inside and just outside the airport perimeter using maximum thrust at take-off, followed by a rapid decrease in engine power as the aircraft flies over noise sensitive locations close to the airport. Engine thrust is increased again when the noise sensitive location has been passed to continue the aircraft climb. Although these procedures are designed for noise abatement over specific locations, they can also result in increased fuel burn and emissions at low altitudes. Primary Noise: Motivated by noise reduction at specific locations near the airport; Adverse Fuel, Climate, Air Quality: High thrust at low altitudes can increase fuel burn and emissions at low altitudes; Easy: Does not require any extra equipment, technical development or stakeholder changes. Does require procedural changes, but these have already been implemented in basic form; Weak: Adverse fuel, air quality, and climate impacts. Noise benefit per departure is small and restricted to the local airport and surroundings.
A A A P Easy Weak
D-1.3: Continuous climb A continuous climb departure is a procedure that eliminates level segments as much as possible all the way from the terminal area to cruise altitudes. Primary Fuel: Motivated by climb fuel reduction; Secondary Climate, Air Quality, Noise: Secondary benefits from emissions and noise reduction from spending less time at low altitudes; Medium: Requires changes to existing departure procedures (and possibly airspace too); Moderate: Can be implemented at a wide range of airports, but with modest fuel and noise benefits.
P S S S Med Mod
D-1.4: Dispersal headings Dispersal headings are often used to increase runway capacity by fanning flights out across the sky enabling use of smaller separations between successive departures from the same runway. Diverging course headings allow for reduced separation on departures, better runway utilization, and greater departure efficiency. Dispersal headings also spread the noise from departing aircraft over a wider area. Secondary Fuel, Climate, Air Quality, Noise: Primarily designed to increase throughput, hence reducing delay resulting in secondary fuel burn, emissions and noise benefits; Easy: Does not require any extra equipment, technical development or stakeholder changes at airports where dispersal headings are available given airspace configuration; Weak: Some fuel, emissions and noise benefits when possible, but not applicable at many airports without major airspace changes.
S S S S Easy Weak
D-1.5 Trajectories to minimize population noise exposure Generation of a noise optimized departure given the population distributions, meteorological data, aircraft performance, navigation and airspace constraints. Primary Noise: Mitigation is aimed at noise reduction; Adverse Fuel, Climate, Air Quality: Longer flight paths can result in greater fuel burn and emissions compared to a more direct departure trajectory; Medium: Currently used in some forms. Requires new procedure design and possible airspace modifications, but not any new aircraft technology; Strong: Can be implemented at a wide range of airports and offers noise reduction for all departure operations by equipped aircraft, but adverse effects likely to limit applicability.
A A A P Med Strong
D-1.6: Max initial-climb departures Maximum climb on take-off to get the aircraft as high as possible as quickly as possible. (Complementary to D-1.2 and D-1.3). Primary Noise: Mitigation is aimed at noise reduction; Secondary or Adverse Fuel, Climate, Air Quality: Possibly offers secondary fuel and emissions savings due to more efficient initial climb, but could also increase low altitude fuel/emissions (see D-1.2); Easy: Does not require any major policy or stakeholder changes and has been successfully implemented in the past; Moderate: Can be implemented at wide range of airports, but with modest benefits.
S/A S/A S/A P Easy Mod
D-1.8: Ensure use of entire runway Using the entire runway length (i.e. not intersection or displaced departures) allows departing aircraft to get higher outside the airport perimeter, reducing noise. Alternatively, using more of the full runway length for the take-off roll permits greater use of lower (de-rated) engine thrust settings on take-off. This leads to maintenance cost savings, as well as to lower take-off fuel burn and emissions and lower engine noise, but may lead to a slower climb-out (which may increase noise impacts). Net noise effects would have to be explored further. Secondary Fuel, Climate, Air Quality, Noise: Primarily useful for reducing engine maintenance costs. May offer limited secondary fuel, emissions and noise savings; Easy: Does not require any major changes; Weak: Can be implemented at a wide range of airports, but net effects likely to be minimal.
S S S S Easy Weak
D-1.9: Additional departure fixes During departure, aircraft are typically routed to specific departure fixes which aid controllers in sequencing aircraft, while keeping them separated from the other departure and arrival flows. Additional departure fixes can add additional capacity at the TRACON boundary and serve as an alleviating factor for miles-in-trail (MIT) restrictions, which often slow down operations and increase delay. Secondary Fuel, Climate, Air Quality: Primarily designed to increase throughput and reduce delay, which result in secondary fuel burn and emissions benefits; Neutral Noise: Surface noise impacts are negligible; Medium/Hard: Requires changes to airspace, departure procedures and possible new navaids; Weak: Cannot be implemented at all airports due to airspace constraints.
S S S 0 Med/Hard Weak
D-1.10: Operating in best noise configuration Airport configuration and current weather determines which runways are used for arrival and departures, and hence airport capacity, which departure and arrival routes are in operation and which areas are being over-flown. Hence some configurations have lower environmental impacts than others. Primary Noise: Mitigation is aimed at noise reduction; Neutral or Adverse Fuel, Climate, Air Quality: Configurations that minimize noise may require longer flight paths with increased fuel and emissions impacts. Also, best noise configuration may not have the highest capacity, potentially increasing delays and fuel use; Easy/Medium: Easy if simply operate in highest capacity configuration, Medium if technology needed to optimize configuration decision; Strong: Can be implemented at a wide range of airports and offers noise reduction for all departures.
0/A 0/A 0/A P Easy/Med Strong
D-2: Increased flexibility in departure routes
D-2.1: RNAV/RNP Enabled SIDs RNAV/RNP Standard Instrument Departures enable aircraft to fly more precise and flexible departure trajectories potentially including fuel optimized climbs. Primary/Secondary Fuel, Climate: Reduces fuel use by enabling more precise and flexible departure trajectories nearer to optimum profiles, but primary motivation for procedure design may be throughput increases and not directly fuel reduction; Secondary Air Quality, Noise: Most benefits at intermediate altitudes, but some low altitude reduced fuel burn and routing around noise sensitive regions have secondary air quality and noise impacts; Medium: Requires extra equipment and changes to existing departure procedures; Moderate: Potentially significant reductions which can be implemented at a wide range of airports.
P/S P/S S S Med Mod
D-2.2: Increased number of departure routes, multi-laning Multi-laning, or adding multiple parallel routes to existing routes, is one opportunity to create additional capacity in the system. If done in ways consistent with controller structure-based abstractions, the cognitive complexity benefits should delay the onset of congestion. The increased precision of aircraft trajectories in RNAV and RNP operations provides opportunities to ‘multi-lane’ existing flows through the addition of minimally spaced, laterally separated, routes. Adding multiple parallel routes to existing routes create additional capacity in the system and reduce ground delays. Combined with reductions in separation minima, parallel lanes can be deployed within the confines of the existing route structure. Secondary Fuel, Climate, Air Quality: Primarily designed to increase airspace capacity and reduce delay which in turn offers secondary fuel, climate and air quality benefits. Neutral Noise: Impacts primarily at higher altitudes so noise impacts not significantly different; Medium: Requires extra equipment and changes to existing departure procedures; Weak: Cannot be implemented at all airports due to airspace constraints.

C-1: Horizontal route efficiency
C-1.1: Reduced Horizontal Separation Minima (RHSM) High navigational precision should eventually allow for RHSM, leading to higher capacity on an airway, and thus a reduction in inefficient spacing-related maneuvers. Could also enable ‘multi-laning’, increasing capacity. Secondary Fuel, Climate: Primarily motivated by increasing capacity/reducing congestion. Therefore, secondary fuel burn/emissions benefits; Neutral Air Quality, Noise: Applies during the cruise phase of flight at high altitudes so minimal air quality and noise effects; Hard: Requires significant changes to existing procedures, extra equipment, safety analysis; Strong: Can be implemented across the system with significant benefits possible.
S S 0 0 Hard Strong
C-1.2: Minimize lateral route inefficiency The en-route flight environment consists of a network of airways that allow for simpler management of traffic flow by controllers. A set of defined waypoints is used to map these airways. By giving each aircraft more authority in its navigation, aircraft can fly more direct routes, saving fuel burn and potentially avoiding traffic congestion on airways. Primary Fuel, Climate: Reduces cruise fuel burn and emissions by reducing total distance flown; Neutral Air Quality, Noise: Applies during the cruise phase of flight at high altitudes so minimal air quality and noise effects; Medium: Requires changes to existing procedures and current routes but no extra equipment; Strong: Can be implemented at high altitudes across the NAS.
P P 0 0 Med Strong
C-1.3: 3D/4D trajectory with minimal changes 3D trajectories include lateral and vertical elements, while 4D trajectories specify target times at certain waypoints as well. Currently pilots are given many trajectory change commands, like speed or altitude changes, which cause inefficiency. By planning these trajectories in advance, traffic flow can be optimized before flights begin. Using the full potential of these trajectories should minimize the need for unnecessary holding due to unforeseen capacity limitations or weather en route or at the destination. Secondary Fuel, Climate: Primary motivation is improved airspace efficiency and throughput, but this has associated secondary effects of reducing cruise fuel burn/emissions by minimizing ATC-commanded flight plan changes and allowing an optimized flight plan to be followed as closely as possible; Neutral Air Quality, Noise: Applies during the cruise phase of flight at high altitudes so minimal air quality and noise effects; Hard: Requires NextGen 4DT capability; Moderate: Can be implemented across the NAS, but total benefits are unclear.
S S 0 0 Hard Mod
C-1.4: Increased sector size Airspace is divided into sectors that define the boundaries of controller authority. Special protocols must be established to ensure proper handoff of aircraft between sectors requiring aircraft to navigate to specific hand-off points between sectors. In addition, neighboring controllers must coordinate with each other to confirm each handoff. These procedures are workload intensive and may require inefficient routing. A reduction in airspace fragmentation could reduce the number of sector changes required during a flight, thus increasing route efficiency and reducing fuel burn and emissions. Secondary Fuel, Climate: Primary motivation is reduced inefficiency which leads to secondary cruise fuel burn/emissions savings; Neutral Air Quality, Noise: Applies during the cruise phase of flight at high altitudes so minimal air quality and noise effects; Hard: Requires redesign of the airspace; Weak: Can be implemented across the NAS, but potential environmental benefit is probably small.
S S 0 0 Hard Weak
C-2: Vertical Routing Efficiency
C-2.1: Reduced Vertical Separation Minima (RVSM) Reduces the vertical separation of flights above FL290 from 2000 ft. to 1000 ft. Each flight level is reserved for either east or westbound traffic, and the directions alternate, so in areas where RVSM is not in place, same direction traffic is separated by 4000 ft. (as compared to 2000 ft. with RVSM). Thus RVSM allows aircraft to fly closer to their optimal altitude and increases flow capacity, reducing inefficient separation maneuvers. Secondary Fuel, Climate: Primary motivation is increased capacity in cruise sectors, which reduces congestion and hence has secondary fuel burn and emissions benefits; Neutral Air Quality, Noise: Applies during the cruise phase of flight so minimal air quality and noise effects; Easy: Currently implemented and does not require any alterations to existing procedures or equipment; Strong: Can be (and is currently) implemented at high altitudes across the NAS.
S S 0 0 Easy Strong
C-2.2: Increased directional airways Using uni-directional airways allows same-direction traffic to be separated by 1000 ft., as compared to 2000 ft. for standard bi-directional airways under RVSM (see C-2.1). This allows aircraft to fly closer to their optimum altitude, but may also reduce lateral efficiency if additional airways needed for opposite direction flows (unless multi-laning is also applied). Primary Fuel, Climate: Primary motivation is allowing aircraft to fly closer to their optimum altitude, reducing fuel burn and emissions; Neutral Air Quality, Noise: Applies at high altitudes so minimal air quality and noise effects; Medium: Requires changes to existing airspace but no extra equipment; Moderate: Potential for big impacts from fuel reduction due to improved vertical efficiency, but may be offset by possible reduced lateral efficiency.
P P 0 0 Med Mod
C-2.3: Cruise climb Most domestic flights are flown at a single cruise altitude to minimize pilot and controller workload associated with changing cruise altitudes to get closer to the optimum level. Cruise climb is closer to the ideal trajectory consisting of a slow, relatively linear climb as the aircraft weight decreases as fuel is burned. Primary Fuel, Climate: Mainly aimed at reducing fuel burn and emissions by allowing aircraft to fly at their ideal altitude at all times; Neutral Air Quality, Noise: Applies during the cruise phase of flight at high altitudes so minimal air quality and noise effects; Medium: Requires changes to existing procedures and current routes but no extra equipment; Strong: Significant benefits possible if implemented.
P P 0 0 Med Strong
C-2.4: Domestic step-climb Similar to cruise climbs, except instead of a continuous smooth climb, the aircraft climbs to discrete altitude levels periodically and then flies at that constant altitude until the next climb is warranted. Requires ATC coordination at each step and is less efficient than the continuous cruise climb, but more efficient than a single constant altitude cruise. Primary Fuel, Climate: Mainly aimed at reducing fuel burn and emissions by allowing aircraft to fly close to their ideal altitude at all times; Neutral Air Quality, Noise: Applies at high altitudes so minimal air quality and noise effects; Easy: Can be done now with existing equipment, may need some minor ATC procedure modifications; Moderate: Less efficient than continuous cruise climbs, but far more efficient than a constant altitude cruise.
P P 0 0 Easy Mod
C-2.5: Increase priority for requested/optimal altitudes Aircraft are typically rerouted and given altitude assignments to expedite the overall flow through the airspace, while maintaining a high level of safety. It may be possible to increase the frequency with which the closest to ideal altitude would be granted to pilots without compromising safety/throughput. Primary Fuel, Climate: Mainly aimed at reducing fuel burn and emissions by allowing aircraft to fly closer to their ideal altitude more of the time; Neutral Air Quality, Noise: Applies at high altitudes so minimal air quality and noise effects; Medium: relatively easy to implement with political will, but requires shift in ATC policies; Moderate: Benefits not as much as routine continuous or step climbs.
P P 0 0 Med Mod
C-3: Speed efficiency
C-3.1: Individual aircraft fuel-optimized cruise speeds Airline priorities often dictate that aircraft fly faster than their best fuel speed (e.g. to maintain schedule). Also, ATC assigns aircraft common speeds to aid in their management of traffic flows. Primary Fuel, Climate: Permitting each aircraft to fly at its minimum fuel burn speed would allow for reduced fuel burn; Neutral Air Quality, Noise: Applies at high altitudes so minimal air quality and noise effects; Hard: Requires extra equipment, safety analysis, changes to existing procedures and ATC coordination; Strong: Could have significant benefits on total fuel use and emissions if implemented.
P P 0 0 Hard Strong
C-3.2: Cruise Mach reductions Individual aircraft speeds (C-3.1) creates the problem of traffic conflicts along single-lane airways, so controllers usually command a common speed. If ATC instead reduced the speed along airways by the same amount for all aircraft, most aircraft would be closer to their best economy speed, reducing fuel burn. Primary Fuel, Climate: Motivated by reduction of fuel burn and emissions; Neutral Air Quality, Noise: Applies at high altitudes so minimal air quality and noise effects; Easy: Simple change to existing procedures, but possibly undesirable for other stakeholders; Moderate: Less benefit than all aircraft at optimal speed, but still significant savings if implemented widely.
P P 0 0 Easy Mod
C-3.3: More efficient passing options Aircraft flying on the same airway at significantly different speeds require a passing maneuver. These are often inefficient, e.g. in terms of extra distance. More efficient passing options could minimize extensive reroutes or speed changes, while being an enabler to more efficient cruise speed allocation (see C-3.1 and C-3.2). Primary Fuel, Climate: Enabler to permitting each aircraft to fly at its minimum fuel burn speed; Neutral Air Quality, Noise: Applies at high altitudes so minimal air quality and noise effects; Medium: Requires extra equipment, safety analysis, changes to existing procedures and ATC coordination; Strong: Could have significant benefits on total fuel use and emissions if implemented.
P P 0 0 Med Strong
C-4: Contrail minimization Contrails are thought to have a warming effect on the climate. If conditions under which they form (related to the relative humidity and temperature of the plume relative to ambient conditions) can be accurately forecast, their formation can be avoided. Primary Climate: Avoiding suspect regions reduces any climate impacts of contrails, but net effects unclear once emissions from possible adverse fuel burn are included; Adverse Fuel: Avoidance would likely involve longer flight paths or off-optimal altitudes, causing increased fuel burn; Neutral Air Quality, Noise: Applies at high altitudes so minimal air quality and noise effects; Hard: Forecasting contrail-forming regions is challenging, avoiding them is easy if known; Improvements in forecast ability needed, as well as understanding of the global warming impact of contrails.
A P 0 0 Hard ?
C-5: Polar routing minimization Emissions in polar regions are thought to have a larger environmental impact than the equivalent emissions outside this region. Minimizing aircraft travel through polar regions could potentially reduce these effects, but would result in higher fuel burn. Primary Climate: Avoiding the sensitive polar climate could reduce overall adverse climate impacts; Adverse Fuel: Avoidance procedures involve longer flight paths, causing increased fuel burn, so net benefits unclear; Neutral Air Quality, Noise: Applies during cruise flight at high altitudes; Easy: Rerouting flights is done routinely now; Improved understanding of the local and overall climate effects of polar routings is needed.
A P 0 0 Easy ?

A-1: Advanced approach procedures
A-1.1: Optimized Profile Descents (OPD)/Continuous Descent Approaches (CDAs) A CDA is an arrival procedure with the vertical profile optimized to remove periods of level flight, and therefore keep aircraft higher and at lower thrust for longer than conventional techniques. OPDs extend the concept to top of climb and can also incorporate optimization in the lateral and speed domains as well by leveraging capabilities of the aircraft FMS. Primary Fuel, Climate, Air Quality, Noise: Original primary motivation was noise reduction from CDAs. Now OPDs optimize from higher altitudes to gain fuel/emissions benefits too; Medium: Successfully implemented at some airports, but airspace changes needed for wide implementation; Moderate: Fuel burn relatively low in approach phase, limiting total possible benefit, noise savings can be significant if widespread implementation possible.

A-1.2: Steeper descent & approach Increasing the descent rate in the terminal area keeps the aircraft at higher altitudes a given distance from the airport which will reduce community noise. Further, if a steeper approach could be achieved without noise penalty and without compromising flight safety, then aircraft could land at airports with limited access. A-1.3: Delayed Deceleration Approaches (DDAs) Delay deceleration to final approach speed compared to conventional approach and hence stay in a cleaner aerodynamic configuration for longer with associated lower drag, thrust, fuel burn, emissions and, potentially, noise. Primary Fuel, Climate, Air Quality: Can be designed to improve fuel burn, emissions and noise performance; Secondary Noise: may be secondary noise benefits from lower thrust levels and cleaner aerodynamic configuration for more of the approach; Medium: No extra equipment is needed, but ATC procedure changes may be required, possible impact on throughput; Moderate: Can be implemented at a wide range of airports but ATC procedures may need to be modified to handle the higher aircraft speeds.
P P P S Med Mod
A-1.4: RNAV/RNP Enabled STARs Enable aircraft to fly more precise and flexible arrival trajectories closer to the optimal procedures. Primary/Secondary Fuel, Climate: Reduces fuel use by enabling more precise and flexible approach trajectories nearer to optimum profiles, but primary motivation for procedure design may be throughput increases and not directly fuel reduction; Secondary Air Quality, Noise: Most benefits at intermediate altitudes, but some low altitude reduced fuel burn and routing around noise sensitive regions have secondary air quality and noise impacts; Medium: Requires extra equipment and changes to existing approach procedures; Moderate: Potentially significant reductions which can be implemented at a wide range of airports.
P/S P/S S S Med Mod
A-2: Advanced landing procedures
A-2.1: Displaced landing thresholds A displaced threshold is a landing threshold located at a point further down the runway than the standard. This helps raise the altitude of arriving aircraft outside the airport perimeter and reduces noise impacts as a result. Primary Noise: Increases altitude over surrounding area to reduce noise impact; Neutral Fuel, Climate, Air Quality: The flight profile is identical, so no changes in fuel or emissions; Easy: Landing further down the runway requires no extra capability as long as the runway is long enough for the aircraft. Possible need for additional infrastructure, such as ILS for displaced threshold; Weak: Altitude gained by displacement is marginal and has only a small noise impact.
0 0 0 P Easy Weak
A-2.2: Reduced thrust reverser usage Thrust reversers shorten landing distance and improve the throughput of airports by allowing aircraft to clear the runway faster. However, associated engine thrust increase causes more noise and fuel burn on landing, so reduced thrust reverse has benefits in these areas too. Potential adverse impacts on throughput need to be explored further. Primary Noise: Reduction in noise around the airport is the primary reason for mitigation; Secondary Fuel, Climate, Air Quality: Reduces fuel use and emissions during landing roll; Easy: Most aircraft can land without needing thrust reversers in today's system, so this would be a simple procedure change; Weak: The noise reduction only impacts the area immediately surrounding the airport, and the fuel and emissions effect is small.
S S S P Easy Weak
A-2.3: Reduced flap landing When conditions are appropriate (e.g. long runway, good weather conditions), landing at less than full flap settings is possible. This reduces drag and hence fuel burn. The highest flap setting can generate more drag than lift. Reduced flap landings will not only reduce fuel consumption but also decrease noise and emissions. Landing speed would be increased somewhat so possible impacts on approach procedures and throughput need to be explored further. (Complementary to A-1.3). Primary Fuel, Climate, Air Quality, Noise: Less flap usage reduces drag, which reduces fuel burn, emissions and airframe noise at low altitudes; Easy: Requires no extra capability as long as runway conditions allow; Weak: Actual impacts are small and only affect a very short portion of the flight.
P P P P Easy Weak
A-3: Reduced go-arounds Go-arounds are executed when a pilot aborts an approach, which can be caused by factors such as poor weather conditions, insufficient separation with preceding aircraft, etc. Go-arounds require aircraft to re-enter the approach pattern, causing additional fuel burn, emissions and noise. Needs to be examined further in the context of safety drivers for go-arounds. Secondary Fuel, Climate, Air Quality, Noise: Reduced go-arounds would primarily be a safety benefit. If reduction in the number of go-arounds could be achieved, fuel, emissions and noise benefits would be a secondary benefit; Hard: Go-arounds occur for unpredictable reasons and hence reducing them would be a complex task; Weak: Many go-arounds are safety related and cannot be avoided. The small number than can be avoided would have a minimal effect on environment.
S S S S Hard Weak
A-4: Absorbing delay enroute instead of terminal area If terminal area delays were known in advance, it would be more efficient to absorb the delays at high altitude in cruise (e.g. by small speed reductions or track extension in cruise) where engines are more efficient compared to in the terminal area. (Complementary to C-1.3). Primary Fuel, Climate: Mainly aimed at reducing fuel use and emissions by absorbing delay in a more efficient way at cruise; Secondary Air Quality, Noise: Reduced delay in the terminal area would eliminate some lower altitude emissions and noise impacts; Medium: Requires procedures & tools to support controllers to predict delay in advance and then coordinate between en route and terminal controllers; Moderate: Delay is being moved to more efficient flight regime rather than eliminated, but mitigation could be implemented at a wide range of locations.
P P S S Med Mod

Surface congestion management systems hold potential to significantly reduce fuel burn and emissions through better surface management, for example by absorbing as much delay as possible at the gate or other appropriate location with the engines off.10 Although technology-based surface congestion management systems (S-1.2) may offer the highest system-wide impact, they have non-trivial implementation barriers in terms of automation development and deployment that are likely to make near-term implementation a challenge at a large enough number of airports to realize a large fraction of this potential in the near-term. By contrast, simpler procedure-based systems (S-1.1) are likely to deliver moderate system-wide impact but with less challenging implementation issues and hence they are considered good candidates for near-term mitigation. Airport Surface Detection Equipment – Model X (ASDE-X) surveillance data (S-2.4) can be a major contributor to the development of effective surface congestion management systems and hence priority should be placed on expanding the collection and availability of this data to researchers.

Reduced-engine taxi (S-2.2), where aircraft taxi with some of their engines off, has the potential for moderate system-wide impact and easy implementation in theory, but in practice there can be reluctance from pilots to use it for operational reasons (e.g. starting engines near the departure runway instead of the gate). Exploring these issues in more detail to encourage greater use of this mitigation is warranted. Operational tow-outs (S-2.3) have similar potential taxi fuel burn reduction benefits, but the medium-level implementation challenges are associated with the likely need for airports to acquire greater numbers of clean tugs and an efficient way to return them to the ramp areas. In addition, prior studies have suggested there are some aircraft nose-wheel structural limitations associated with extended towing operations, and these too should be explored in more detail.

Holding or passing areas near runway ends (S-4.3) have moderate system-wide impact potential but pose a medium implementation challenge due to the requirement for additional infrastructure at airports which may not be possible in the near-term. End-around taxiways to minimize runway and queue crossings (S-4.1) have low system-wide impact but slightly easier implementation in the near-term.11

Improved coordination tools (S-5) that enhance information sharing between ATC and operators have significant system-wide impact potential but are difficult to implement due to technical and stakeholder barriers that will probably prevent new mitigations in these areas from being viable near-term opportunities.

The other surface mitigations have relatively weak system-wide impact potential. The taxi fuel minimization mitigations (S-2) are generally easy to implement in the near-term and, like ground power (S-6), are already in use at many airports.
Finally, the runway assignment mitigations (S-3) generally require some form of controller decision support to have any major impact, which makes them hard to implement in short timeframes.

sec.title: Departure (D)
sec.p: Engines typically operate at high thrust settings during take-off and departure operations, and hence mitigations in this phase can have significant fuel burn, emissions and noise impacts. Table 3 shows the results of the departure mitigations evaluation.
Continuous climb (D-1.3) and maximum climb (D-1.6) departures offer moderate system-wide impact with medium or easy implementability and hence may be appropriate for further examination.

Trajectories to minimize population noise exposure (D-1.5) offer strong system-wide impact reduction for noise with medium implementability issues, but there are interesting adverse trade-offs with the other environmental metrics. Operating in the best noise configuration (D-1.10) has also been assessed to have strong system-wide potential for noise together with interesting trade-offs between noise benefits and possible adverse impacts such as increased fuel use and emissions. Both of these mitigations therefore warrant further study. There are similar adverse impacts with optimal thrust cut-back (D-1.2), but this mitigation has a weak system-wide impact.

RNAV/RNP enabled Standard Instrument Departure (SIDs) procedures (D-2.1) offer moderate system-wide impact for fuel and noise with medium ease of implementation. These types of procedure are being explored at several airports, and hence a systematic assessment of their potential across the system would be highly valuable.12
The other departure mitigations were ranked as having a weak system-wide impact and therefore are considered lower priorities for further study than the ones highlighted above.

sec.title: Cruise (C)
sec.p: The cruise phase of flight accounts for the largest proportion of total fuel burn, and hence mitigations here can have significant system-wide impacts. As a result, many of the mitigations in this phase are worthy of careful consideration for further study for near-term implementation. Table 4 shows the results of the cruise mitigations evaluation.

Of the horizontal routing efficiency measures, Reduced Horizontal Separation Minima (C-1.1) and minimizing lateral route inefficiency (C-1.2) are considered to have strong system-wide benefit potential, but neither are easy to implement in the near-term (the former being ranked as hard and the latter as medium). In terms of vertical routing efficiency, Reduced Vertical Separation Minima (C-2.1) has good potential for environmental impact mitigation and has already been implemented in the U.S. Variants of cruise altitude optimization (cruise climb (C-2.3) and domestic step climb (C-2.4)) have significant mitigation potential with easy or medium implementation. Several speed efficiency measures such as cruise Mach reductions (C-3.2) and more efficient passing options (C-3.3) also have strong or moderate system-wide impact potential with medium or easy implementation. These issues are explored in much more detail in Lovegren and Hansman.13

Many of the other mitigations such as optimal individual speed allocation in the cruise phase (C-3.1) hold promise, but are hard to implement because they require major additional equipage, changes to existing procedures or ATC coordination.

sec.title: Approach (A)
sec.p: The approach flight phase accounts for a relatively small amount of overall mission fuel burn because the engines are in low power settings for most of the descent, but there are non-negligible fuel and noise savings to be gained during holding and final approach conditions. Table 5 shows the results of the approach mitigations evaluation.

Optimized Profile Descents (A-1.1), steeper descent and approach (A-1.2), Delayed Deceleration Approaches (A-1.3),14 RNAV/RNP enabled Standard Terminal Arrivals (STARs) (A-1.4)12 and absorbing delay enroute instead of in the terminal area (A-3) all have moderate system-wide impact with medium implementation challenges and hence are all worthy of further exploration for near-term system-wide implementation.

sec.title: Miscellaneous (M)
sec.p: The improved airline/ATC coordination mitigations (M-2) all have moderate system- wide impact with most having medium ease of near-term implementation (a few are ranked as easy) and this is an area where further assessment is clearly warranted. Policy measures (M-3) have potential to have strong system-wide impact, but any mitigation involving policy change are unlikely to be realistic for near-term implementation. But given their impact potential, further study would clearly be useful for implementation in somewhat longer time timeframes. Table 6 shows the results of the miscellaneous mitigations evaluation.

sec.title: Topics selected for further study
sec.p: The systematic identification and qualitative assessment against common performance metrics described in the previous section provides important insights into the potential environmental mitigation options in the near-term. In the second phase of this work, several mitigation areas were selected for more detailed study based on a number of selection criteria, including the desire to have at least one study from each flight phase, mitigation potential, gaps in the current research literature and complementarity to other on-going mitigation study areas. This section summarizes the key findings from the more detailed studies in four areas: End-around Taxiways (S-4.1); RNAV/RNP Departure and Approach Procedures (D-2.1/A-1.4); Vertical and Speed Cruise Efficiency Improvement (C-2/C-3); and Delayed Deceleration Approaches (A-1.3). These brief descriptions of the follow-on studies illustrate how the qualitative information can be validated and built upon to gain further insights into mitigation options.

sec.title: End-around taxiways
sec.p:
End-around taxiways (EATs) eliminate runway crossings and can increase runway throughput, and reduce taxi time and fuel use. This section describes a case study of EAT use at Dallas/Fort-Worth International Airport (DFW) where arrivals on runways 17L and 17C have the option of either taking a conventional taxiway across runway 17R to get to the terminal buildings, or alternatively taking an EAT around the end of 17R (Figure 2). The conventional taxiway results in a shorter taxi distance, but crossing 17R causes interactions with 17R departures which can increase taxi time compared to the EAT route which is effectively de-coupled from 17R operations. ASDE-X data was analysed for operations between 15 September 2010 and 13 December 2010 to quantify to first order the impact of an EAT on fuel burn and emissions reduction and to determine the factors, issues and conditions under which these reductions are observed. For more detailed results please see Uday et al.11 Figure 2.
Simplified representation of EAT layout at DFW.

The use of the end-around taxiway was found to be highly dependent on factors such as runway configuration, traffic conditions, and controller and pilot preference. As a result, the number of aircraft using the EAT was varied from being used by all aircraft to not being used at all. Overall, 54% of the 17L arrivals used the perimeter taxiway. The maximum time taken to taxi via the conventional (non-EAT) taxiway was higher by more than 2 minutes compared to the maximum time taken to taxi via the EAT. Consistent with previously published results,15 taxi times on the end-around taxiway showed less variability (with standard deviation values approximately 30 seconds lower) than those found for the conventional taxiway. This could potentially lead to improved gate and runway scheduling for the airport. Further, the maximum fuel burned by an aircraft using the conventional taxiway was significantly higher than the maximum fuel burned by an aircraft while using the EAT, while the average fuel burned on the EAT was less than on the conventional taxiway. The standard deviation of the total fuel burned was less in the case of the EAT.

These observations indicate that EATs have the potential to provide benefits consistent with the evaluations presented in the previous section, especially in high-traffic situations when frequent stops and starts on the conventional route are likely. EATs are fairly easy to implement, provided an airport has the necessary space. Concerns about aircraft on the EAT appearing to be crossing active runways have been addressed by placing a screen between the end of the runway and the EAT, or by depressing the EAT below the level of the runway. In continuing work, decision models to minimize fuel burn by appropriately selecting the conventional or end-around taxiway at different airports are being developed.

sec.title: RNAV/RNP Procedures
sec.p: RNAV/RNP is a combination of avionics and procedures that allows precision approaches. It was originally developed to improve safety and increase access to high terrain airports. Since RNAV/RNP procedures can result in more efficient and precise arrival and departure trajectories and shorter path lengths, a reduction in total fuel burn and congestion is possible.16–18 Noise mitigation can be achieved by limiting the populations that are flown over by ensuring repeatability of flight tracks (though this must be traded against the increased exposure of populations under the precision flight track), or by ensuring flight tracks are over unpopulated areas, such as rivers. This section describes a case study of an arrival procedure at Seattle-Tacoma International Airport (SEATAC) to quantify to first order the impact of an RNAV procedure on fuel burn and emissions reduction and to determine the factors, issues and conditions under which these reductions are observed. For more detailed results see Muller et al.12

The results indicate that properly designed RNAV/RNP procedures can yield fuel and emissions savings during approach of up to approximately 40% (the potential savings per operation for the approach segment, not the potential savings per flight). However, these maximum benefits are only realized when procedures are optimized. The majority of existing RNAV procedures are overlays, which are merely higher precision, satellite-based designed versions of existing ground-based procedures. These procedures are easier to develop and pass through environmental review, but they do not yield as much fuel benefit; in fact, the accompanying noise concentration may result in increased noise complaints. Airlines are also reluctant to retrofit with the more advanced RNP equipment because the benefits of overlays are too small. In contrast, new, optimized, procedures do require significant effort and can be blocked by impacts identified during the environmental review process or community resistance, due to displacement and concentration of the noise footprint. In the short term, we can therefore expect that penetration of optimized procedures will remain limited. Future work will focus on identifying the best target airports and procedures for the development and uptake of optimized RNAV/RNP procedures.

These observations indicate that while RNAV/RNP procedures do have the potential to provide benefits consistent with the evaluations presented in the previous section, these benefits will only be realized if procedures are optimized and if they are implemented in a manner that addresses environmental and community concerns.

sec.title: Cruise efficiency
sec.p: The cruise phase represents the largest fraction of total fuel burn and correspondingly the largest opportunity for fuel burn and emissions reduction. A study was conducted which focused on the potential efficiency benefits that can be achieved by improving the cruise speed and altitude profiles operated by flights today and findings are reported in full in Lovegren and Hansman.13 Flight data was collected for 257 flights during one day of domestic US operations. A process was developed to calculate the cruise fuel burn of each selected flight, based on aircraft performance and atmospheric data. Improved speed and altitude profiles were then generated for each flight, representing various levels of optimization. Optimal cruise climbs and step climbs of 1000 and 2000 ft were analyzed, along with optimal and Long Range Cruise speed profiles. Results showed that a maximum fuel burn reduction of 3.5% is possible in cruise given complete altitude and speed optimization; this represents 2.6% block fuel reduction system-wide (i.e. accounting for all the other flight phases which are not directly impacted by these cruise mitigations), corresponding to 300 million US gallons of jet fuel and 3.2 million tons of CO2 saved annually. These are significant savings potential which reinforce the ‘Strong’ system-wide benefits potential identified in the initial assessment. Flights showed a larger potential from improved cruise speed performance, with nearly 2.4% savings possible from speed optimization compared to 1.5% for altitude optimization. The barriers identified in the first phase of the work were largely confirmed, but the more detailed follow-on study allows mitigating these barriers to be viewed in perspective of how much saving might be possible if they were to be overcome. Few barriers were found to exist to some of the strategies such as step climbs and lower speeds, making them potentially attractive in the near term to realize a portion of this estimated benefit. As barriers are better understood and hence potentially mitigated, more of this significant system-wide benefit could be realized.

sec.title: Delayed deceleration approaches
sec.p: Delayed deceleration approaches (DDAs) primarily hold potential for reduced fuel burn and emissions by allowing aircraft to stay in clean aerodynamic configuration and low thrust for longer during approach operations compared to conventional approaches. There may also be noise benefits resulting from lower engine thrust levels and cleaner aerodynamic configuration for more of the approach path, but these effects need further study. Such approaches are often not conducted today due to air traffic and flight crew procedures which slow aircraft early in the approach, and overcoming this tendency is likely to be a major barrier to implementation. In order to assess the benefits potential of DDAs, operational data from flight data recorder (FDR) archives were used to study variations of fuel burns with key parameters of interest, e.g. airspeed, flap, power, etc. profiles. A full description of the methodology and full results are presented in Lovegren and Hansman13 and Dumont,14 but they can be summarized as 30%–40% fuel saving potential below 10,000 ft for flights using DDAs compared to the average approach procedure. This equates to up to a 2% block fuel burn saving on typical commercial aircraft flights. Based on these results, estimates of US system-wide impacts were made: if all US flights conducted DDAs, fuel savings of 290 million US gallons per year (US$0.58–1.2 billion across all operators at US$2–4/US gallon price) and reductions of 2.8 million metric tons of CO2 per year could be possible. However, due to barriers to implementation, only a fraction of this ‘benefits pool’ is likely to be realizable, but if only 1% of US flights were to fly DDAs, fuel savings of 2.9 million US gallons per year (US$5.8–11.6 million worth at US$2–4/US gallon price), and reductions of 28,000 metric tons of CO2 per year would be possible. These potential benefits are somewhat smaller in magnitude compared to the cruise efficiency findings, confirming the ‘moderate’ fuel reduction potential system-wide, but the savings are still significant. They justify a more detailed assessment of the barriers to implementation that need to be overcome to realise these benefits, which is now underway, including focused stakeholder engagement.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: This article has discussed a research study to undertake a comprehensive identification and systematic evaluation of near-term operational changes to determine the relative environmental mitigation potential, as well as other factors such as barriers to implementation. Over 75 mitigations with the potential to reduce environmental impacts were identified based on a combination of literature review, aviation stakeholder interviews and industry knowledge between the research team and the FAA project sponsors. In this article, the 61 purely operational mitigations were discussed. The mitigations were qualitatively assessed in terms of their potential environmental benefit, ease of implementation and overall system-wide impact potential. Results for the operational mitigations identified have been presented in terms of their assessment rankings and what they mean in terms of which ones may be appropriate for further study and implementation.

One final point to note is that although the mitigations have been presented as independent, in reality there are important interdependencies. For example, absorbing delay en route instead of in the terminal area (A-4) relates to mitigations which change cruise speeds (C-3.1 and C-3.2), which are in turn related to enablers to making speed changes viable, such as more efficient passing options (C-3.3) and multi-laning (D-2.2). Such interdependencies affect the overall potential of each mitigation and this research can help identify these connections.
